    swingtree.style.LibraryInternalCrossPackageStyleUtil
  • Deprecated Methods
    Method
    Description
    swingtree.AbstractDelegate.setMaxSize(Dimension)
    swingtree.AbstractDelegate.setMinSize(Dimension)
    Use AbstractDelegate.setMinSize(Size) instead!
    swingtree.AbstractDelegate.setPrefSize(Dimension)
    Use AbstractDelegate.setPrefSize(Size) instead of this method.
    swingtree.AbstractDelegate.setSize(Dimension)
    Use AbstractDelegate.setSize(Size) instead of this method!
    swingtree.components.JSplitButton.addSplitButtonActionListener(SplitButtonActionListener)
    Use JSplitButton.addButtonClickedActionListener(swingtree.components.action.ButtonClickedActionListener) or JSplitButton.addSplitButtonClickedActionListener(swingtree.components.action.SplitButtonClickedActionListener) instead.
    swingtree.components.JSplitButton.removeSplitButtonActionListener(SplitButtonActionListener)
    Use JSplitButton.removeButtonClickedActionListener(swingtree.components.action.ButtonClickedActionListener) or JSplitButton.removeSplitButtonClickedActionListener(swingtree.components.action.SplitButtonClickedActionListener) instead.
    swingtree.style.ComponentStyleDelegate.component()
    because it introduces the following two issues:
    • SwingTree styles are expected to be side effect free functions. The JComponent however is mutable and very sensitive to repaints. Mutating a component in a styler can lead to things like endless repaints and other bugs which are extremely hard to track...
    • A developer may want to access the dimensions of a component to perform rendering in a custom Painter. Unfortunately, the dimensions of a component are not in "developer pixels"! Instead, they are already scaled to the current UI.scale(). To prevent scaling issues, use ComponentStyleDelegate.componentWidth() and ComponentStyleDelegate.componentHeight(). These are scaled to "developer pixel"
    swingtree.style.ComponentStyleDelegate.parent()
    because it introduces the following two issues:
    • SwingTree styles are expected to be side effect free functions. The parent of a JComponent however is mutable and very sensitive to repaints. Mutating a component in a styler can lead to things like endless repaints and other bugs which are extremely hard to track...
    • A developer may want to access the dimensions of a component to perform rendering in a custom Painter. Unfortunately, the dimensions of a parent component are not in "developer pixels"! Instead, they are already scaled to the current UI.scale().
    swingtree.style.ComponentStyleDelegate.peek(Peeker<C>)
    because it introduces the following two issues:
    • SwingTree styles are expected to be side effect free functions. The parent of a JComponent however is mutable and very sensitive to repaints. Mutating a component in a styler can lead to things like endless repaints and other bugs which are extremely hard to track...
    • A developer may want to access the dimensions of a component to perform rendering in a custom Painter. Unfortunately, the dimensions of a parent component are not in "developer pixels"! Instead, they are already scaled to the current UI.scale().
    swingtree.style.LibraryInternalCrossPackageStyleUtil._onlyBorderInsetsOf(Border, Component)
    swingtree.style.LibraryInternalCrossPackageStyleUtil.applyFontConfAlignmentsToComponent(FontConf, JComponent)
